{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3720448,"name":"Archit ","username":"bupersob","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bupersob/{size}/264721_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T18:05:21.307Z","cooked":"

My team has struggled with bumpers for years. Teams with “clean” bumpers what techniques have you guys used to assemble them? Finger Joints? What kind of backing materials are you using? wood? bent aluminum? How do you mount them to your frame? If anyone has any pictures or insight on any of them it would certainly help raise the floor on bumpers for all!

This link has some things about it already. Our team uses 1/4 20 camera quick connects and few can lift the whole robot on four of them from holding the bumpers. They slide together and have a 1/4 20 thread on each side.

Captain Obvious here:

Remember, your robot WILL bump into things. Bumpers are an important feature of your robot’s design, like your drivetrain, intake, scoring mechanisms, electrical system, etc. They need to be well engineered, like those other things. Not an afterthought.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T18:21:42.702Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":469,"readers_count":468,"score":188.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/5","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720539,"name":"CEF","username":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T19:49:00.806Z","cooked":"

The new rule as of last year is that there are minimal gaps allowed in bumper coverage. That makes building a solid square tempting. Advise against doing that and, instead, doing bumpers in multiple pieces.

Why? Two reasons:
(1) Squares must be lowered over the entire robot infrastructure and pulled off the same way. That’s a nuisance.
(2) It’s not as easy to make a square as you’d think. And you have less ability to make adjustments.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T20:10:36.951Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":135.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Paul Regnier","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61214,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2102 Lead Programmer and OA Lead"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/7","custom_user_title":"2102 Lead Programmer and OA Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720597,"name":"","username":"Coco","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/8797f3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T20:59:34.105Z","cooked":"

The usage of a solid square bumper is still a good option, if it is done right. My team has done it the last couple years and we have some very, very clean and resilient bumpers. It may be the easier option to opt for bumpers in multiple pieces, but those are also more likely to have things go wrong (such as falling off the robot) during a match. There are pros and cons to both.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T20:59:34.105Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":363,"readers_count":362,"score":157.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":28649,"username":"CEF","name":"CEF","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/35a633/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70618,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720605,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-21T21:07:26.631Z","cooked":"

There are any number of good bumper construction methods. What are your teams resources that may be relevant? Do you have access to a large enough CNC router to cut bumper backer? Do you have a someone with woodworking skills? Do you have a particular preference for some other fabrication technique? What is your end goal? Durable bumpers with a minimum of fuss, bombproof bumpers that will never be damaged, pretty bumpers? Do you want easy to build mounts, fast to use mounts, very rigid mounts, mounts that are very tolerant to misalignment?

Broadly speaking:

  • I haven’t seen a compelling reason to use anything other than plywood for your backer, but it must be quality plywood, minimum 3/4" ACX or 12mm BB/BB baltic birch.
  • Design in a gap between the bumper and the robot frame, I use .030".
  • Remember that fabric has thickness, a frame the fits great bare will not fit great with 6 layers of cordura in the corners.
  • If you can’t hit plus or minus .03" or better on the inside dimensions of your bumper frame, consider looking for a more precise manufacturing method or doing 4 piece bumpers. I think it would be possible to make some COTS solutions to help in this area.
  • Figure out how you are going to wrap fabric around your corners before its crunch time. I highly recommend CADing bumper fabric as sheet metal and exporting flat pattern to sew, but some people get decent results with folding the excess fabric.

Here’s a bunch of other info. ( The formating will look very weird without the Space Age font)
Comets Bumper Guide REV 2.docx (17.0 MB)

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-21T21:07:26.631Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":350,"readers_count":349,"score":135.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/uploads/short-url/xZuR0qktnn9geIy63KBsgzNy30V.docx","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/9","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720784,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T00:31:42.040Z","cooked":"

Box joints (similar to finger joints) 1/2 inch plywood last year (would have used 3/4 regardless in 2024). And thru bolt mounting. One piece bumpers.

IMG_20240222_1959321920×876 248 KB

Bumper boards are a bit oversized relative to ribot perimeter to allow for fabric to be stapled in the back. There is probably a ~1/8" gap all the way around for this allowance. We did the bumper boards in the router this year. That worked great for the joints and the holes for the thru bolts.

We followed the cirtus slash 111/2 approach to mounting, but crutially the bumpers flex their mounting slightly before the frame takes contact and it is an abrupt transfer of energy. I think this is part of the reason we had good luck with bumpers. I can elaborate more if need be.

Here is the mounting from a few angles.

20250201_1523291920×1440 345 KB

20250128_2027591920×2560 466 KB

20250208_1052421920×2560 437 KB

20250221_2030241920×1440 371 KB

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-22T00:33:55.724Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":85.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/10","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720790,"name":"wyatt","username":"stormsj28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a3d4f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T00:52:26.007Z","cooked":"

Bumper material can also matter a ton, (not sure if this has been mentioned yet) this year we went with a slicker material, although could be punctured easily we never got caught on algae because it didn’t want to “grab” our bumper, it would roll and slide around. With that said I know that some intakes (jack in the bots) would likely not work with our bumper material because it would compress differently in different spots and could slide the coral easier which may cause issues. Having two half’s to a bumper is also very easy to put on and off with a 40 inch robot (top is about 58 on the cart I think) and on person can very easily put on both half’s (with our quick connects mentioned earlier) this also makes it easier to make the bumpers (imo) because you can preload the noodles against eachother

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-22T00:52:26.007Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":281,"readers_count":280,"score":76.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"wyatt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76247,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3218 CAD"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/11","custom_user_title":"3218 CAD","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720804,"name":"Zach Hoegberg","username":"Zaque","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zaque/{size}/257827_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T01:32:59.529Z","cooked":"
Skyehawk:

One piece bumpers.

IMG_20240222_1959321920×876 248 KB

Not sure if this was just a mock-up before final assembly, but note that if you do one piece bumpers (or 2 c shapes or anything else with built-in corners), wrapping noodles like in that pic is no longer legal per R406 blue box A.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-22T01:32:59.529Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":80.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Zach Hoegberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20681,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/12","custom_user_title":"112 Drive Coach | 111&112 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3720805,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T01:34:55.221Z","cooked":"

(That’s the 2024 robot, but yes going forward totally correct)

(In this instance I am pretty sure that was a mock up to boot XD )

Coco:

The usage of a solid square bumper is still a good option, if it is done right.

The problem is right here …IF it is done right

How many teams end up with a frame perimeter that EXACTLY matches the CAD model?

Your manufacturing tolerances are always within spec?

Never had a problem “shimmying” a 1 piece bumper over the robot?

Everything always lines up the first time?

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-22T16:07:42.359Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":155.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Christine Low","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32239,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Bumper Queen"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/15","custom_user_title":"Bumper Queen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721273,"name":"Wen Pan","username":"Wen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wen/{size}/264371_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T17:47:13.365Z","cooked":"

On our team we have bumpers with jointed wood frames. the wood frame worked reliably for the past few years but this year one of our bumper’s wood frame connections broke. the glue came loose. We are planning on adding aluminum brackets on the broken joints. The wood frames are covered with pool noodles. The pool noodles are then wrapped onto the frame with duct tape. Pool noodles have proven reliable, although over time the duct tape has become slightly loose(not a big issue though).
for connection we have quick release pins. those pins are connected to the robot aluminum frame though brackets on the bumper. They are easy to use and make the bumper super quick to add or remove. The only issue we had with those bumpers is the joints of the wood pieces would break over time, we recommend having aluminum brackets for additional strength in the joints.

image1137×462 147 KB

We do have a large enough CNC to cut a bumper backer, not very strong wood working skills. Our goal is to create bumpers that are as robust as possible, with reliable/rigid mounting. It would also be cool to have some pretty bumpers

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-08-22T18:04:10.183Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":62.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505515,"topic_slug":"everything-bumpers","display_username":"Archit ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52597,"username":"Patrick3357","name":"Patrick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69721,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 2583 Lead"},"post_url":"/t/everything-bumpers/505515/17","custom_user_title":"FRC 2583 Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3721364,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-22T21:06:42.336Z","cooked":"

Okay great, then you can build precise, strong bumper frames pretty easily. You’ve got 2 basic options for the corners, box joint with epoxy or metal brackets. If you do box joints, I recommend ~1/2" tabs, and thixo epoxy. Wood glue or gorilla glue will not be strong enough, you need an epoxy designed for wood. If you go for aluminum brackets you will need both an inner and outer bracket for rigidity and strength, and that will probably require custom sheet metal. Use good plywood, if you can find a real lumber yard that supplies fine carpenters in your area, I’d highly recommend bb/bb baltic birch plywood or BS-1088 marine plywood. Remember, the whole point of using the CNC is you should be holding a .01" tolerance on the final assembly, so don’t let oversized holes or out of square glue ups mess up your bumper. Mistakes will require you to start over with new plywood. CAD in a .03" gap all the way around your robot you don’t want the bumper too tight for fabric or bumper changes.

Mounting I think there are 2 main options here worth talking about. Threaded mounts, either a stud or nut mounted to the robot frame and hole on the mounting bracket. On the plus side this is pretty easy to do with no special parts but on the minus side you can cross thread and loose your fasteners. Personally I prefer sliding clips (McM #1872A111) because you cannot loose any parts once they have been mounted and they are extremely fast to use. They do require fairly high precision so not a good idea unless you have that down already, and the carriers they come with will break over a season so I’d recommend replacing or reinforcing them with something stronger.
